questions.text: Which of the following changes in extracellular ion concentrations will make a nerve most excitable at rest? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Increasing extracellular K+ makes a nerve most excitable because it depolarizes the resting membrane potential. When extracellular K+ increases (hyperkalemia), the concentration gradient for K+ decreases, reducing K+ efflux from the cell. This causes the resting membrane potential to move closer to the threshold potential, making the neuron more excitable. In mild to moderate hyperkalemia, this decreased gradient leads to K+ accumulation inside cells, causing depolarization and increased excitability.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Decreasing extracellular Na+ Decreasing extracellular Na+ primarily reduces the frequency of the action potential but has minimal effect on the resting membrane potential. This occurs because Na+ permeability is relatively low at rest (0.04 compared to K+ at 1), so changes in Na+ concentration have little impact on excitability. Option B. Increasing extracellular Na+ The permeability of the membrane to Na+ at rest is relatively low, so increasing extracellular Na+ has little effect on the resting membrane potential or excitability. The RMP is primarily determined by K+ gradient since K+ has much higher permeability at rest. Option D. Increasing extracellular Cl- Increasing extracellular Cl- would push the membrane potential more negative (hyperpolarization) since Cl- influx has a hyperpolarizing effect. This would move the membrane potential further from threshold, making the neuron less excitable.
  • • Option A. Decreasing extracellular Na+ Decreasing extracellular Na+ primarily reduces the frequency of the action potential but has minimal effect on the resting membrane potential. This occurs because Na+ permeability is relatively low at rest (0.04 compared to K+ at 1), so changes in Na+ concentration have little impact on excitability.
  • • Option A. Decreasing extracellular Na+
  • • Option B. Increasing extracellular Na+ The permeability of the membrane to Na+ at rest is relatively low, so increasing extracellular Na+ has little effect on the resting membrane potential or excitability. The RMP is primarily determined by K+ gradient since K+ has much higher permeability at rest.
  • • Option B. Increasing extracellular Na+
  • • Option D. Increasing extracellular Cl- Increasing extracellular Cl- would push the membrane potential more negative (hyperpolarization) since Cl- influx has a hyperpolarizing effect. This would move the membrane potential further from threshold, making the neuron less excitable.
  • • Option D. Increasing extracellular Cl-

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The resting membrane potential is primarily determined by K+ gradient, and alterations in extracellular K+ concentration have significant effects on neuronal excitability - hyperkalemia increases excitability by bringing the membrane potential closer to threshold.

questions.text: What is the most effective treatment for frostbite on the lower extremities? (NEET PG 2015)

options.label: C
options.text: Rewarming with immersion in warm water

options.label: D
options.text: Rewarming with encouragement to walk on warm surfaces

questions.correct_answer: C. Rewarming with immersion in warm water
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The initial treatment for frostbite is rapid rewarming in a bath at 42°C. This method provides controlled rewarming at a specific temperature to prevent further tissue damage. Rapid rewarming is essential, but it must be done properly in a warm water bath to ensure even heat distribution and temperature control.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Rewarming with friction and/or massage - This is actively dangerous for frostbite. Frostbite causes delayed microvascular damage similar to cardiac reperfusion injury. Friction or massage would worsen this damage by potentially breaking fragile tissues that are already compromised.
  • • Option A. Rewarming with friction and/or massage
  • • Option B. Rewarming with blankets - This method is too slow and uncontrolled. Frostbite requires rapid rewarming at a specific temperature (42°C), which blankets cannot provide consistently.
  • • Option B. Rewarming with blankets
  • • Option D. Rewarming with encouragement of walking on warm surfaces - This would apply pressure to already damaged tissue. The level of damage is difficult to assess, and management is conservative until there is absolute demarcation of the level of injury. Walking would risk further injury before proper assessment.
  • • Option D. Rewarming with encouragement of walking on warm surfaces

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Frostbite requires controlled, rapid rewarming in a water bath at a specific temperature (42°C) without applying pressure or friction to the damaged tissues, followed by conservative management until tissue demarcation is clear.

questions.text: Which ion primarily drives the depolarization phase of action potential in cardiac muscles? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The action potential in cardiac muscles is initiated by the rapid influx of sodium ions (Na+) during Phase 0, the phase of rapid depolarization. This sudden influx results from the opening of fast sodium channels, which causes a sharp rise in the membrane potential towards a positive value. This process is crucial for initiating the sequence of electrical events that lead to muscle contraction. Sodium's role is pivotal in setting the fast response of cardiac myocytes, which differentiates cardiac muscle action potential from those in other types of muscle cells.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option a. K+: While potassium ions (K+) play significant roles in the initial repolarization (Phase 1) and final repolarization (Phase 3) by exiting the cell, they do not initiate the action potential. Option c. Ca+2: Calcium ions contribute mainly to the Plateau phase (Phase 2) of the cardiac action potential by entering the cell through slow voltage-gated channels, sustaining the depolarization longer than in other muscle cells, but they are not the primary trigger. Option d. Cl: Chloride ions have minimal direct involvement in the generation or progression of cardiac action potentials.
  • • Option a. K+: While potassium ions (K+) play significant roles in the initial repolarization (Phase 1) and final repolarization (Phase 3) by exiting the cell, they do not initiate the action potential.
  • • Option a. K+:
  • • Option c. Ca+2: Calcium ions contribute mainly to the Plateau phase (Phase 2) of the cardiac action potential by entering the cell through slow voltage-gated channels, sustaining the depolarization longer than in other muscle cells, but they are not the primary trigger.
  • • Option c. Ca+2:
  • • Option d. Cl: Chloride ions have minimal direct involvement in the generation or progression of cardiac action potentials.
  • • Option d. Cl:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The initiation of the action potential in cardiac muscle cells is primarily driven by the influx of Na+ ions during the rapid depolarization phase, critical for the subsequent phases of the cardiac cycle.

questions.text: Most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients is ( INICET Nov 2023
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Malignancy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In hospitalized patients, the most common cause of hypercalcemia is malignancy. Malignancy-associated hypercalcemia often results from the secretion of parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP) by cancer cells, which mimics the effects of parathyroid hormone, leading to increased calcium levels. This is frequently seen in cancers such as breast cancer, lung cancer, and multiple myeloma.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Primary hyperparathyroidism: This is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in outpatients but not in hospitalized patients. It is characterized by elevated levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) due to parathyroid gland hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma.
  • • Option B. Primary hyperparathyroidism:
  • • Option C. Vitamin D toxicity: Hypercalcemia can occur due to excessive intake of vitamin D, leading to increased intestinal absorption of calcium. However, it is not the most common cause in hospitalized patients.
  • • Option C. Vitamin D toxicity:
  • • Option D. Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia: This is a rare genetic condition characterized by benign hypercalcemia with low urinary calcium excretion. It mimics primary hyperparathyroidism but is less common and typically not seen as the most frequent cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients.
  • • Option D. Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Malignancy is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients, often due to the secretion of PTHrP by cancer cells.

questions.text: Which muscle is responsible for shoulder abduction between 15° and 90°? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The deltoid muscle is primarily responsible for abduction of the shoulder joint from 15° to 90°. Specifically, the middle fibers of the deltoid are powerful abductors of the arm at the shoulder joint. The deltoid is a triangular muscle that covers the shoulder joint and gives the shoulder its rounded contour. It is innervated by the axillary nerve (C5, C6). The multipennate arrangement of its acromial fibers allows for strong abduction force, making it the main muscle for this movement range.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option a) Supraspinatus - While controversial, the supraspinatus is traditionally thought to initiate abduction (0°-15°) rather than being the primary muscle for 15°-90° abduction. It works synergistically with the deltoid throughout the range of motion.
  • • Option a) Supraspinatus
  • • Option b) Trapezius - The trapezius does not directly abduct the shoulder joint. Its role in shoulder abduction becomes important only beyond 90° when it rotates the scapula to allow continued overhead movement.
  • • Option b) Trapezius
  • • Option d) Serratus Anterior - This muscle is responsible for protraction of the scapula and works with the trapezius for scapular rotation during overhead abduction (90°-180°), but is not the primary muscle for 15°-90° glenohumeral abduction.
  • • Option d) Serratus Anterior
  • • Education Objective:
  • • Education Objective:
  • • The deltoid muscle is the principal abductor of the shoulder joint from 15° to 90°, while complete overhead abduction (beyond 90°) requires coordinated action between the deltoid, trapezius, and serratus anterior. According to latest edition of Gray’s Anatomy (0°-15°) is controversial. New updates are saying that (0°- 90°) movement is done by deltoid & supraspinatous both muscles.

questions.text: Which antiepileptic drug specifically enhances the inactivation phase of voltage-gated slow sodium channels, helping to stabilize hyperexcitable neurons? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lacosamide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Lacosamide has a unique mechanism of action among antiepileptic drugs. It selectively enhances slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels. While most sodium channel blocking antiepileptics (like phenytoin, carbamazepine) act on fast sodium channels, lacosamide specifically targets slow sodium channels. This mechanism helps stabilize hyperexcitable neuronal membranes and prevents repetitive neuronal firing.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Phenytoin : Incorrect. While it does act on sodium channels, it primarily blocks fast sodium channels, not slow sodium channels. It acts by promoting the inactive state of these channels.
  • • Option A. Phenytoin
  • • Option B. Lamotrigine : Incorrect. Like phenytoin, it acts primarily on fast sodium channels and also affects calcium channels. It does not specifically target slow sodium channels.
  • • Option B. Lamotrigine
  • • Option C. Felbamate: Incorrect. It works primarily as an NMDA receptor antagonist and has no significant effect on sodium channels, either fast or slow.
  • • Option C. Felbamate:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lacosamide uniquely acts by enhancing the slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels, distinguishing it from other sodium channel-blocking antiepileptics that act on fast sodium channels.
